content.webTitle: Mark Bennett: Vern Cotter has fuelled squad’s return to Scotland way

fields.headline: Mark Bennett: Vern Cotter has fuelled squad’s return to the Scotland way
fields.bodyText: Scotland have not lacked for ambition in recent years but against Argentina they revealed a new clinical ability to finish off a top-10 nation that lit up a dank Edinburgh night. The Pumas were decidedly off the pace but the key to this first Murrayfeld win over Argentina since 1990, according to the debutant in the side, was a return to a high-tempo style of play. Yet, after struggles under the Scot Frank Hadden, the Englishman Andy Robinson and the Australian Scott Johnson, it is the New Zealander Vern Cotter who has apparently brought a change of focus. He sought the advice of former Scotland players and coaches Andy Irvine, Jim Telfer and Ian McGeechan, and then shared his thoughts on a style of play with the players. The centre Mark Bennett believes that fuelled Saturday’s performance. “In the squad there has been a sort of realisation that we were going away from the Scottish way,” said the 21-year-old. “We’ve tried to bring that back, looking at our roots and the heritage of our game. We’re bringing back that fire that was maybe slightly lacking before. Vern has fuelled that, bringing in his style and speaking to these guys and trying to find the Scottish way of playing, and we found that against Argentina.” Bennett, who played under Cotter in the Clermont Auvergne youth system, was not one of the five try-scorers against the Pumas but was a crucial component in Scotland’s early dominance as forwards and backs linked well and possession was maintained through a high tempo that sucked in defenders and created space for others. The Ayrshire lad would have had a try had his Glasgow team-mate Jonny Gray executed a two-on-one and released him but Bennett agreed that error in an otherwise outstanding display by the lock was typical of a team performance that showed plenty of positives but also aspects requiring work. Scotland had responded to a gift of a score for the pacy Argentina flanker, Javier Ortega Desio, in only the second minute with quickfire tries from Richie and Jonny Gray that exploited the sin-binning of Juan Imhoff for a late hit and provided a long-awaited Scotland finish to slick buildup play. The scrum-half Greig Laidlaw was the deserved man of the match behind an impressive pack and it was his rejuvenated breaking ability that created tries for Sean Maitland before half-time and Stuart Hogg just after, which, when added to Laidlaw’s conversions and a penalty, put Scotland 34-10 ahead and killed the game as a contest. What happened next should tax the minds of players and coaches as Scotland slipped off the pace, 14 replacements entered the fray and Argentina seized their chance to restore some pride. Scotland lost forwards Rob Harley and Jim Hamilton to yellow cards as pressure mounted and the penalty count rose, and Argentina scrummaged to a penalty try and maintained pressure for the replacement scrum-half Tomás Cubelli to cross twice in the final five minutes. An interception score by Tommy Seymour before the final double ensured Scotland were never in danger of losing but the final score took the gloss off what could easily have been a record victory. Memories of a six-try 42-17 win over Japan at this point last year being followed by a 28-0 thumping from the Springboks, should also focus minds as New Zealand pitch up in Edinburgh. “They’re very pleased with the effort and the result,” Cotter said, “but we’re in no position to get carried away. The All Blacks beat England and they’re the best team in the world. “We’ll take a very positive approach to the game against the All Blacks … and how the game unravels will be important to us because we’re going to get something from this game. “But the first thing we must do is not get carried away: be brutally honest with ourselves, which I know these guys are, try and develop what we did well and try to identify a few things which they’ll be trying to exploit, and take those opportunities away from them.” Sam Hidalgo-Clyne has been drafted into the squad as cover for Henry Pyrgos, the replacement scrum-half suffering concussion amid the Puma fightback, but the experienced Chris Cusiter will step up to the bench on Saturday if Pyrgos is ruled out. Scotland Hogg; Maitland, Bennett, Dunbar (Lamont, 75), Seymour; Russell (Weir, 65), Laidlaw (capt, Pyrgos, 64, Laidlaw 79); Dickinson (Reid, 69), Ford (Lawson, 64), Murray (Cross, 70), R Gray (Hamilton, 69), J Gray, Harley, Cowan (Strokosch, 60), Ashe. Tries R Gray, J Gray, Maitland, Hogg, Seymour. Pen Laidlaw 2. Cons Laidlaw 4, Weir. Argentina Tuculet; Imhoff, Bosch (Agulla, 60), Hernández, Montero; Sánchez (Iglesias, 53), Landajo (Cubelli, 58); Ayerza, Creevy (capt), Herrera (Chaparro, 45), Lavanini, Guillemain (Ponce, 69), Baez (Isa, 17), Desio, Senatore. Tries Desio, penalty, Cubelli 2. Pen Sánchez. Cons Sánchez, Hernández 3. Referee W Barnes (Eng). Att 36,764
